author: dragan2836472
content:
Question:

Imagine we have 2 storage slots that we want to save to the trie. For that we need to derive the trie-keys for them. Example:

pedersen_hash(address1,trieIndex1 / 256) -> 0x0c8ca4aa6d74880db2c2bf3adfae2ac9cf01ebeb590403293d9c70aa07c3090a

and

pedersen_hash(address2,trieIndex2 / 256) ->
0x0c8ca4aa6d74880db2c2bf3adfae2ac9cf01ebeb590403293d9c70aa07c3090b

These 2 only differ in last byte - i guess this is possible. Since we are chopping of last byte for the subIndex(trieIndex % 256) that means the value would be overwritten in the trie. Or it could be they differ in first byte (it could be that we reverse bytes here, but the issue is the same)

So:
Is having same 31bytes(first 248bits) for different input in pedersen(MSM which produces a banderwagon element serialized to base field (x coordinate), so its 253 bits (which is still larger than 248bits)) considered negligable?

I know <@774033563732541451> did some testing regarding this here: https://gist.github.com/jsign/cb633d1439050b81906a53ea3f083405

But I'm not sure how to interpret those (I guess the case I described above is considered negligable, but want to confirm?)

author: jsign
content:
That case that you describe should be negligible (if I understand your question correctly). This fact is not specific to Verkle Trees but any other kind of hashing function, since your output domain is bounded in size.
The same applies to sha256 or any other hashing function... there will be collisions for sure, just that they're designed to be hard to be intentionally found.

author: jsign
content: Yes. I mean, chopping bits of course increase the probability by  2^bits but if you still consider all the remaining ones is quite a lot. (assuming all output bits are uncorrelated/uniform)
